description: From Middle English blusteren (“to wander about aimlessly”); however, apparently picking up the modern sense from Middle Low German blüstren (“to blow violently”; compare later Low German blustern, blistern). Related to blow, blast. Compare also Saterland Frisian bloasje (“to blow”), bruusje (“to bluster”).

verbs.description: bluster (third-person singular simple present blusters, present participle blustering, simple past and past participle blustered)

examples: When confronted by opposition his reaction was to bluster, which often cowed the meek.

entries.meaning: To act or speak in an unduly threatening manner.
examples: Your ministerial directors blustered like tragic tyrants.

entries.meaning: To blow in strong or sudden gusts.
